mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Multigenic Drosophila Model of Colorectal Cancer Reveals Complex Signaling Networks Mediating Tumorigenesis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a complex heterogeneous disease characterized by multiple mutations affecting critical signaling pathways. Limitations in therapeutic treatments due to the development of resistance mechanisms, toxicity, and relapse of metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) have led to its high mortality rate worldwide. The epistatic interactions of aberrant signaling pathways in CRC contribute to the complexity and limitations of treating this disease. Thus, rapid development and identification of new potential druggable options in CRC is essential. Drosophila is a particularly useful model organism to dissect molecular mechanisms underlying CRC and to find potential new druggable targets. In this dissertation, we looked at critical signaling pathways driving CRC progression to identify novel therapeutically targetable nodes. Two important aspects affecting intestinal transformation in CRC genetic landscapes in Drosophila are the alteration of global phosphorylation networks driving CRC and the role of oncogene-induced-senescence (OIS). The regulation of phosphorylation of important pathways involved in cancer development and progression is governed by kinases and as a result, kinases are frequent targets of drug discovery efforts. However, target identification of kinases that are drivers of disease phenotype is challenging in cancer with mutations in multiple pathways. In this dissertation we report 2 classic genetic modifier screens focusing on Drosophila kinome to identify kinase regulators in 2 different CRC genetic backgrounds: KRAS TP53 PTEN APC, a multigenic cancer model targeting 4 recurrently mutated genes in human colon tumors and KRAS alone, a simpler single hit model targeting one of the most common altered pathways in cancer. Results from the screens in Chapter 2 suggest that classic genetic modifier screens in heterozygous mutant background with a modest reduction in candidate gene activity is a particularly useful approach for systemic drug treatment in identifying the most rate-limiting genetic vulnerability in disease model as ideal candidate drug targets. Additionally in this dissertation, we demonstrate that intricate epistatic interactions of underlying multi-kinase pathways in KRAS TP53 PTEN APC drive tumor progression via OIS. Senescence plays a crucial role in cancer, though this role can be either tumor-suppressive or tumor-promoting, depending on the genetic context and the microenvironment. The highly heterogeneous, dynamic, and context-dependent nature of senescence-associated features and the relatively small numbers of senescent cells in tissues make in vivo mechanistic studies of senescence challenging. As a result, which senescent-associated features are observed in which disease contexts and how they contribute to disease phenotypes remain largely unknown. Similarly, the specific mechanisms by which various senescence-inducing signals are integrated in vivo to induce senescence and why some cells become senescent while their immediate neighbors do not are unclear. In this dissertation, we identify a small number of cells that exhibit multiple features of senescence in a genetically complex model of CRC-induced intestinal transformation, in the Drosophila larval hindgut epithelium. These cells emerge in response to concurrent activation of AKT, JNK, and DNA damage response pathways within the transformed tissue. Eliminating senescent cells, genetically or by treatment with senolytic compounds, reduces overgrowth and improves survival. This tumor-promoting role is mediated by Drosophila macrophages recruited to transformed tissue by senescent cells, which results in non-autonomous activation of JNK signaling within the transformed epithelium. These findings emphasize complex cell-cell interactions as potential druggable nodes in cancer.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
cell signaling, colorectal cancer, Drosophila, druggable nodes, kinase, senescent cells

Erdem Bangi, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michelle N. Arbeitman, University Representative; Henry W. Bass, Committee Member; Jiang Feng, Committee Member; Kathryn M. Jones, Committee Member; Jerome Irianto, Committee Member.
